content.question: Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a differentiable function such that <math alttext="f of 4, equals 7 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="f prime of 4, equals, one fifth" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is concave up on the interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 3 comma 5, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is true about the approximation for <math alttext="f of 3.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> found using the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="f of 3.5, is approximately equal to 6.9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>6.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and this approximation is an overestimate of the value of <math alttext="f of 3.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="f of 3.5, is approximately equal to 6.9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>6.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and this approximation is an underestimate of the value of <math alttext="f of 3.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="f of 3.5, is approximately equal to 7.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>7.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and this approximation is an overestimate of the value of <math alttext="f of 3.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="f of 3.5, is approximately equal to 7.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>7.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and this approximation is an underestimate of the value of <math alttext="f of 3.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="f of 3.5, is approximately equal to 6.9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>6.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and this approximation is an underestimate of the value of <math alttext="f of 3.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Explain how an approximated value relates to the actual value.
